group.name: Stimuli

description.p: Module used for reading numerical input data from a text file. The data is represented in the file as a number of columns given names in a header. Each set of columns will be available as an output vector from the module with the same name as the columns.
The following example shows how the header describes the number of columns in each output vector and its name:

The first output will get the name "X" and consists of two values while the second output will be called "Y" and contain three elements. Each row in the file corresponds to the output from an InputFile module at each time step.
Comments can be added in the data file after a hash sign (#) as in the following example:
description.pre: # This is a comment; this line will be ignored in the input X/2 Y/3 10 2.0 12 5 8 # This is also a comment 2 31 5.4 10 1 # and this : :
description.p: Blank lines in the file are skipped. When the whole file has been read, the module send an end-of-file signal to the IKAROS kernel that will stop the execution. This is useful in off-line simulations.
InputFile can read files using any of the three popular line terminators: CR, LF, or CR+LF.

parameter.name: filename
parameter.description: File to read the data from

parameter.name: iterations
parameter.description: Number of times to iterate the files

parameter.name: extend
parameter.description: Number of additional time steps to run before the module sends the end-of-file signal to the IKAROS kernel. This attribute is used to allow the data in the input file to propagate through the network of modules before the execution is terminated.

parameter.name: print_iteration
parameter.description: Print the iteration number to standard out

output.description: The outputs generated from columns in the file.

group.limitation: It is not possible to loop the data file indefinitely.

group.name: OUT

description.p: Module used for writing numerical data to a text file. The data is represented in the file as a number of columns given names in a header. The first column is called "T" and contains the time (in ticks) when the row was written. All other columns in the output file are defined in the XML file.

The following example shows how the header describes the number of' columns in each output column and its name. The file could have been produced by the above module definition if the input vector to "X" had one value and the input to "Y" had two values.
As default there are four decimals in each column. This can be changed with the decimals attribute:
description.pre: <module class = "OutputFile" name = "OUT" filename = "data.txt" decimals = "0" > <column name = "X" /> <column name = "Y" decimals = "2" /> </module>
description.p: Here, the attribute decimals in the module tag sets the default decimals to none for all columns. This is changed locally for column Y where 2 decimals are used. The example above will now become:

parameter.name: filename
parameter.description: File to write the data to

parameter.name: decimals
parameter.description: Number of decimals for all columns

parameter.name: column
parameter.description: Definition of a column in the output file; name attribute sets the name of the column; decimals sets the number decimals of this column

input.description: The module can have any number of inputs; each will generate a column in the output

group.limitation: It should be possible to supress the timing column "T".
